importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, and is part of a broader discussion about internet platform degradation, making it a timely and current analysis relevant to ongoing debates about tech regulation and platform accountability.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article outlines a three-stage model of platform degradation (Stage 1: growth, Stage 2: business favoritism, Stage 3: user and business harm), illustrating how platforms evolve from user-friendly to exploitative over time.

keyTakeAways: Enshittification is a process where internet platforms degrade from user-centric to profit-driven models, eventually harming both users and businesses.

Platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber exhibit stages of enshittification: initially attracting users with good value, then favoring business partners, and finally exploiting both users and businesses to recoup investor profits.
Key mechanisms of enshittification include predatory pricing, network effects, high switching costs, and algorithmic manipulation.
Amazon is accused of cloning products, charging junk fees (up to 51 cents per dollar earned), and manipulating search results to favor its own offerings.
Facebook is accused of changing feeds to prioritize ads, forcing publishers to publish longer excerpts, and charging to boost content, even when users follow the publishers.
Doctorow blames lack of competition and weak consumer regulation for allowing platforms to degrade, calling for stronger antitrust enforcement and the abandonment of the consumer welfare standard.

Proposed solutions include 'right-to-exit' regulations (e.g., allowing Kindle users to take e-books with them) and increased interoperability (e.g., allowing Android apps on iPhones, cross-platform messaging).
Despite Amazon and Facebook denying the claims, Doctorow cites studies and data to support his assertions about pricing, search quality, and business exploitation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article presents a theory of 'enshittification' — the degradation of internet platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber — as they evolve from user-friendly, early-stage platforms into exploitative systems that prioritize profit over user and business well-being. The theory outlines three stages: Stage 1 (user acquisition with good value), Stage 2 (favoring businesses at user expense), and Stage 3 (exploitative pricing, algorithmic manipulation, and high switching costs). Doctorow attributes this decline to a lack of competition and weak consumer regulation, and proposes solutions such as stronger antitrust enforcement, abandoning the consumer welfare standard, implementing a right-to-exit policy, and promoting interoperability across platforms. While Amazon and Facebook deny these claims, Doctorow cites studies and data to support his assertions, particularly around Amazon's pricing and search quality. The article is part of a growing anti-tech monopoly movement and underscores the need for regulatory reform to protect internet users and small businesses.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
